bibl.title: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, July 18, 1937

div1.p: Moran introduces himself to Hench and will send him an account of his experiences with the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, July 18, 1937

July 18, 1937.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
MAYO CLINIC,
Rochester, Minn.
My dear Doctor Hench:
div1.p:
Your very kind letter dated July 6th reached me a few days
ago, delay in receiving same being due to deficiency in address. Since
my brief talk on the radio on January 18th, I have received over 250 fan
letters. Most of them were addressed to me here in Havana but many came
thru Lowell Thomas and the NBC Studios in Rockefeller Center, the few
words I had to say being on Lowell Thomas' program and from the Studios
of the NBC in Radio City. They appear to have my “number” at the Gen-
eral Post Office here, by this time. Most of the letters were addressed
to John J. Moran, Havana, Cuba. All letters showing my full name were
promptly delivered to me, in as much as I happen to be the only “John J.
Moran” listed in the telephone directory. It is pertinent to note here
that there are a number of Morans listed in the 'phone directory, all
Spaniards or of Spanish origin, except myself, the surname Moran being
as typically Spanish as it is Irish. So much by way of introduction.

Within a few days I will send you a fairly complete and entirely
accurate account of the yellow fever experiments carried out here by the
“Reed & Carroll” Board. Having acted as clerk-secretary to Major Reed
while awaiting my turn at Camp Lazear, and with a very clear memory of
the events leading up to and taking place during that “now famous episode”,
as somebody has put it, I believe I am qualified to relate facts. I shall
be pleased to pass same on to you in my own fashion and style. You can
cull what you wish from my disjointed account of the experiments and word
them in your own style, in a much more lucid manner than mine, I have no
doubt. I will ask you to be patient with me for a few days while I pre-
pare the “story” for you.

I have been living in Havana since March 1, 1928, and expect to
live my few remaining years here. I visit the home office of Sun Oil
Company once every two or three years and shall probably not make another
trip to the U. S. before 1939. This company is a subsidiary of Sun Oil
Company and I am its manager and treasurer. Perhaps you may happen to be
in Havana next year or the year after. If so, I shall feel honored in
meeting you.
